qas.question: What sort of LEDs are becoming more available on the market?
What is the range of wavelengths for cheap UV LEDs?
Shorter wavelength diodes provide wavelengths as low as what?
What UV wavelengths are found in sterilization devices?
What substance does nitrides not contain?
What sort of non-LEDs are becoming more available on the market?
What is the range of wavelengths for cheap UV LEEDs?
Longer wavelength diodes provide wavelengths as low as what?
What UV wavelengths are found in non-sterilization devices?

context: With nitrides containing <a0_0><b5_0>aluminium<b5_0/><a0_0/>, most often AlGaN and AlGaInN, even shorter wavelengths are achievable. <a1_0><b6_0>Ultraviolet<b6_0/><a1_0/> LEDs in a range of wavelengths are becoming available on the market. Near-UV emitters at wavelengths around <a2_0><b7_0>375–395 nm<b7_0/><a2_0/> are already cheap and often encountered, for example, as black light lamp replacements for inspection of anti-counterfeiting UV watermarks in some documents and paper currencies. Shorter-wavelength diodes, while substantially more expensive, are commercially available for wavelengths down to <a3_0><b8_0>240 nm<b8_0/><a3_0/>. As the photosensitivity of microorganisms approximately matches the absorption spectrum of DNA, with a peak at about 260 nm, UV LED emitting at <a4_0><b9_0>250–270 nm<b9_0/><a4_0/> are to be expected in prospective disinfection and sterilization devices. Recent research has shown that commercially available UVA LEDs (365 nm) are already effective disinfection and sterilization devices. UV-C wavelengths were obtained in laboratories using aluminium nitride (210 nm), boron nitride (215 nm) and diamond (235 nm).
